# Contextualizing Sensitivity Analysis in Observational Studies

Lucy D'Agostino McGowan  
Robert A Greevy, Jr

---
layout: true

.footnote[\#JSM2017]
---
_Inspite of there being good methods out there, sensitivity analyses aren't being done. Lit review in top tier journal we saw 4% difference. Big push to make these understandable and really make this a common practice_
set the stage 
In the last analysis you did you do a sensitivy analysis
DId these in RHC
SMD plot - standardized way of showing balance in observation study before and after matching/weighting
show just SMD - here is a standard plot that is getting included a lot more, we think it should be in every paper - it shows balance/inbalance in each of the covariates 
what this doesn't show you the imporatance of that particular covariate in teh final estimate. To really understand how important these coveriates are, we need to understand how much these covariates moved the estimate itself
interested on impact on point-estimate of exposure
3 things that will make a covariate important - it needs to be predictive of the exposure (imballanced) predictive of the outcome (a strong beta in the model) it needs to be fairly independent of the other covariates included 
DNR is not the most imbalanced covariate - it is super predictive and is pretty independent from the other covariates
Unless you have clinical reason to believe that you have another covariate like DNR, then you may base your sensitivity analysis on 
- even if we had missed something as big a DNR, we still would be ok
- discuss outcome + exposure
- show whole graph then show cropped for the rest
- tell RHC story
Imbalanced
predictive of outcome
independent of other covariates
